div1.p: Earle describes the history of yellow fever in Puerto Rico prior to the American occupation and includes a table with a summary of deaths due to yellow fever in various years.

div1.head: Report: Yellow Fever in Porto Rico, by Walter C. Earle, [1923] [Enclosed in C0302058]
div1.p:
The following briefly summarizes the history of yellow fever prior
to the American occupation. The source (1) does not indicate from whence the
disease came nor its mortality when here. In 1813 a report on yellow fever for
the education of the people was made by the city council of San Juan. In 1816
there was a severe epidemic of a disease which was thought probably to be yellow
fever, and which affected mainly Ponce. Nothing further is found until 1865
when it is merely mentioned that an epidemic of yellow fever existed. In 1877
there was an epidemic affecting among other places San Juan. This lasted on into the year
of 1878. The following table gives a summary of the deaths due to yellow fever
from 1890-1899 with the per cent of total deaths due to that cause. Most of the
cases are reported from San Juan, Mayaguez, and other seaport towns.

div1.p:
Dr. Pedro del Valle (2) states
that in 1895 while he was in charge of the
military hospital in San Juan there was a
severe epidemic in which approximately
out of 600 soldiers attacked 400 died.
The cases were introduced from Cuba by
ships sailing between Cuba and Spain. The
disease spread gradually throughout the
island running its course until all
susceptibles had been attacked. It was
gradually found that people in the coast towns were much less susceptible to
the disease than those in the inland towns, probably because they had had an
attack of the disease previously. It was his opinion as well as that of Drs.
Gutierrez and Ashford that yellow fever has never been endemic here but has been
brought in chiefly from Cuba. Dr. Juan Guiteras (3) states that yellow fever
ceased to exist in Porto Rico after strict quarantine was enforced and ships
- 2 -
coming from Cuba with sick soldiers aboard were prohibited from stopping at
San Juan. Dr. Del Valle confirms this and states that previously practically
the only steamship communication was with Cuba, Santo Domingo, and indirectly
with Mexico. In former times the Spanish Transatlantic Steamship Co. was a
powerful organization and when a ship of that company was quarantined at San Juan
for yellow fever a complaint was made to the Governor. Offering the excuse that
yellow fever was endemic here anyway the Governor would release the ship from
quarantine and the cases would be brought ashore to introduce an epidemic. Since
strict quarantine has been established shortly before and since the American
occupation there have been no authentic cases of yellow fever in the island. In
1901 (4) one case was reported from Arecibo but did not result fatally nor were
there any further cases. (5) It was thought by the doctor who investigated the
case that a wrong diagnosis had been made. In October and November of 1915 a
number of cases with fever of short duration and a slight eruption appeared in
San Juan and were diagnosed as yellow fever by the doctor in the military hospital.
The diagnosis could not be confirmed by his associates but since he persisted in
calling the cases yellow fever, Drs. Gorgas, Carter, and Mariano Lebredo were
called in to investigate. They did not believe that the cases were yellow fever
and thought that dengue was a more likely diagnosis. Other doctors reported
numerous similar cases at that time as yellow fever but in none of them could
the diagnosis be confirmed. Not even a suspicious case has been reported since
then.

(1) Report of Military Governor of Porto Rico. 1900 pp. 555-589.
pp. 616-620.

(2) Dr. Del Valle was in charge of the military hospital in San Juan
previous to the American occupation and has been in the quarantine station
San Juan since that time.

(3) Boletin Official de la Secretaria de Sanidad y Beneficencia de Cuba. 1917
Ano.viii- Tomo xvii.“ Recientes Observaciones sobre la Fiebre Amarillo.”
Juan Guiteras.
(4) Report of Governor of Porto Rico 1901.
(5) Report of Governor of Porto Rico 1916.
